awd_titl_txt: Arithmetic Intersection on Shimura Varieties and Properties of Abelian Varieties
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project concerns work in arithmetic geometry, a branch of mathematics that studies polynomial equations over the integers. Such equations define geometric objects; among them the most accessible and fundamental ones are elliptic curves (one-dimensional case) and abelian varieties (higher-dimensional analogue). A modern way to approach these objects is to study them in families, and certain geometric objects, so-called Shimura varieties, have been used to parametrize these families. Arithmetic properties of abelian varieties can be translated into arithmetic-geometric properties of the corresponding Shimura variety. In this way, the principal investigator and her collaborators will be able to use methods from different areas of mathematics such as algebraic geometry, number theory, and representation theory to study the arithmetic of abelian varieties.

The main theme of this project is the infinitude of certain thin sets of primes arising from reduction types of abelian varieties. When the abelian varieties are over number fields, the principal investigator and her collaborators are aiming for results along the line of Elkies' theorem on supersingular reductions of elliptic curves. The research will focus on nonsimple reductions or reductions with higher Picard rank and establish a general framework to treat certain abelian varieties of arbitrarily high dimension. In the function field case, certain new phenomena appear and are related to the geometry of the Newton strata of the corresponding Shimura variety. The philosophy of this project is related to the Kudla program on arithmetic intersection of special cycles on Shimura varieties. In addition to the usual setting of the Kudla program, certain non-special cycles are studied in the framework of this project.

por.por_cntn:
This project proved new results in various aspects of the arithmetic of abelian varieties and K3 surfaces using Shimura varieties. More precisely:

  1. The PI in a collaboration with A.N. Shankar, A. Shankar, and S. Tayou, proved that every K3 surface over a number field has infinitely many reductions with extra elements in the Picard group (under certain technical assumption later removed by Tayou). A more general result on the intersection of arithmetic 1-cycle and special divisors on GSpin Shimura varieties was proved by the PI and her collaborators and yielded other applications to abelian varieties. (One article has been accepted for publication on journals)
  2. The PI in a collaboration with D. Maulik and A.N. Shankar proved the global function field analogue of the main results above. As an application, the PI and her collaborators proved a special case of the Hecke orbit conjecture of Chai and Oort. (Two articles have been accepted for publication on journals.)
  3. The PI in a collaboration with W. Li, E. Mantovan, and R. Pries studied cyclic families of curves, especially the special families in a paper of Moonen. The PI and her collaborators studied the intersection of the Torelli locus and the Newton strata in various PEL type Shimura varieties and the infinitude of the basis reductions of one-dimensional special families. (One article has been accepted for publication and one article is under preparation.)

 

The results of the project have been presented in many seminars, conferences, and workshops.

The PI is a co-organizer of the MSRI special semester ?Diophantine Geometry" in Spring 2023 and a co-organizer of sessions in 2022 AWM (Association for Women in Mathematics) Research Symposium. The PI has supervised 4 undergraduates on junior papers (one semester research experience) on topics related to the results of the project.
